meaning_mnemonic: If you put your <radical>mouth</radical> on a <radical>tree</radical> and try to eat it, you’re probably a <kanji>distressed</kanji> and <kanji>troubled</kanji> individual (unless you’re a woodchuck). You don’t need to eat this tree, you have plenty of food at home. Get your mouth off that tree you distressed child.
A <radical>flood</radical> and a <radical>fire</radical>! At the same time? This is a <kanji>disaster</kanji>!

Next to a <radical>tree</radical>, you spot <radical>poop</radical>, not once but twice. Only a <radical>drunkard</radical> would be the type of <radical>person</radical> to not use the nearby <kanji>machine</kanji> toilet. There's a perfectly good outhouse with a machine toilet right there, but this drunkard is so drunk that he decides to poop under the tree instead. And not only does he poop once, he poops twice.

Sitting on the <radical>lid</radical> of a toilet, you're praying your <radical>poop</radical> <radical>explosion</radical> will be flushed away, beseeching the <radical>cross</radical> decorating the bathroom wall. The poop needs to be one hundred <kanji>percent</kanji> flushed away because you're on a date, and you don't want even one percent of your explosion left for them to see.
The <radical>fly</radical> radical and the <kanji>fly</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Awesome!

You slip off the <radical>roof</radical>, your <radical>life</radical> flashes before your eyes, and you smash your <radical>mouth</radical> on the ground causing some serious <kanji>damage</kanji>. Oof, this is a really bad <kanji>injury</kanji>, you fell all the way off the roof and onto your mouth.

Regardless of whether or not you wear a <radical>hat</radical> while you <radical>jackhammer</radical>, you’re going to have a <kanji>surplus</kanji> of noise. Jackhammers are loud, and your hat is doing nothing to dampen the racket. There’s a surplus of commotion coming from the jackhammer and onlookers are not amused.

A <radical>Chinese</radical> <radical>turkey</radical> is <kanji>difficult</kanji> to find because they are so rare. Chinese turkeys are the rarest variety of turkey, so naturally, finding one is exceedingly difficult.

A <radical>spirit</radical> loses its <radical>skin</radical> as a part of the damage it <kanji>incur</kanji>s after death. That's why the spirit goes on looking for new skin to <kanji>cover</kanji> itself with.
In <radical>spirit</radical> <radical>valley</radical>, spirits are <kanji>abundant</kanji>. Hence the name. Spirit valley has over two billion spirits floating in it.
<radical>Rain</radical> causes a <radical>landslide</radical> that causes an <kanji>earthquake</kanji>!!! The earth doesn't just slide, it <kanji>shake</kanji>s and <kanji>quake</kanji>s.
You take some <radical>flag</radical>s, <radical>nine</radical> in total, and put them one by one up your <kanji>butt</kanji>.

You see a <radical>flag</radical> stuck in the ground with a little bit of <radical>fur</radical> coming out from it and on closer inspection you realize it’s actually a <kanji>tail</kanji>. Someone stuck a flag into some sort of animal, pushing it under the ground. All that’s visible now is some fur and part of the tail.

Under a <radical>tree</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> sits with <radical>twenty</radical> little <kanji>contraptions</kanji>. There's little electronic ones, little bopping ones, little walking ones... twenty of them.
You take a <radical>stone</radical> to the <radical>forehead</radical> of a <radical>turkey</radical>. It is <kanji>certain</kanji> that you will damage it.
When a <radical>woman</radical> sees the <radical>Mona Lisa</radical>, she feels a strong feeling of <kanji>dislike</kanji>. All women dislike the Mona Lisa because of how much attention she gets.

The <radical>leader</radical>'s <radical>mouth</radical> has grown <radical>old</radical> from saying so many things. This is what makes them different from everyone else, they speak truly like an <kanji>individual</kanji>.
Under any <radical>cliff</radical>, there's some <radical>dirt</radical> that's under a lot of <kanji>pressure</kanji>.

A <radical>narwhal</radical> sticks a <radical>stick</radical> into the <radical>dirt</radical> to see what might <kanji>exist</kanji> underneath it. Narwhals live in the sea, you see. So they're convinced nothing can exist anywhere else.

A <radical>flowers</radical> <radical>net</radical> is upon your <radical>forehead</radical> in the <radical>evening</radical>. These appear on your head at night whenever you are having a <kanji>dream</kanji>.

You <radical>stand</radical> on the <radical>Cliff</radical> of <radical>Life</radical> and <kanji>give birth</kanji> to a child. Oh no! You’re standing too close to the edge of the Cliff of Life! The baby falls off the cliff right after you give birth to it! In your despair, you throw all your <kanji>property</kanji> off the cliff too.

Someone stabbed the <radical>leader</radical> <radical>mole</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> to <kanji>overthrow</kanji> it. Now there is a new mole leader. Because that's what happens when you overthrow someone—someone else needs to take over. In this case, a vengeful mole.
Wash your<radical>self</radical> with a <radical>big</radical> bar of soap if you're <kanji>stinking</kanji> everything up.

Hanging off the edge of a <radical>cliff</radical> is a <radical>sun</radical>-worshipping <radical>child</radical> with a <kanji>thick</kanji> unibrow. Hanging off the cliff, the child cries out to the sun to save them from this cruel fate. Even the thickness of their unibrow is not enough to give the child the strength to climb back up on their own.
You place a <radical>cross</radical> on a <radical>Wolverine</radical> <radical>woman</radical>. She's gone now, but she was once your <kanji>wife</kanji>.

What you <radical>say</radical> is <radical>righteousness</radical>, at least that's what you believe. You keep talking and saying these things, and you don't listen to anyone else's words. This is your style of <kanji>deliberation</kanji> and <kanji>discussion</kanji>.

In the <radical>animal</radical> kingdom, a <radical>snake</radical> is the most likely to commit a <kanji>crime</kanji>. Remember the Garden of Eden? The snake was the bad guy. Ever since then, snakes are the animal most known for committing crimes.

Put a <radical>net</radical> around a <radical>criminal</radical> to show their <kanji>guilt</kanji>. Criminals look like anyone else on the street, so you decide to tie them in nets to make sure people know who they're dealing with.

If there is a <radical>building</radical> in the <radical>direction</radical> you want to go it will <kanji>prevent</kanji> you from going any further. Like, come on kid, you think you can just walk right through a building? Don't make me laugh!

You <radical>say</radical>, throwing your <radical>hat</radical> on the <radical>ground</radical> in front of the <radical>bookshelf</radical>, "I have a <kanji>theory</kanji>!" All this reading and thinking has finally given you a wonderful idea, a theory you think might solve all of your problems!

Tying a <radical>thread</radical> to a <radical>tombstone</radical> each year will help you <kanji>manage</kanji> the <kanji>passage of time</kanji>. That way you’ll know how many years you <kanji>pass through</kanji>, since you’ll have one thread for each year to count.

You walk into this <radical>tree</radical> and hit your <radical>head</radical> on it, then a <radical>knife</radical> falls out of it to <kanji>stab</kanji> you. Ow! What the heck?! What was a knife doing in that tree?
